text:
There's a lot of judgment around debt that is 
not fair and it's not right but it's there, and

you want to just protect yourself from it, 
the way you'd protect a friend from it.

Hey everybody. I'm Marielle Segarra, the host 
of NPR's Life Kit, and that is
Stacey Vanek Smith, a Global Economics Correspondent for NPR.
I have been covering business and economics for about 18 years.
Stacey has spent a lot of time talking to people about money, and today, we're

exploring debt: why so many people have it, how to 
get out of it, and even how to negotiate a better
interest rate with your credit card company.
So many people are in debt right now. Prices have been rising, government stimulus isn't really happening anymore,
and now credit card debt is rising at one of the fastest rates ever.
What would you say is the biggest misconception about this topic?
People associate being in debt with being irresponsible or being careless.
Like, "Well you should just you know just spend less. You should just learn to budget."
And I've talked to a lot of people who are struggling with debt right now... a lot. And
almost every case there was just a big life event that happened and they couldn't catch back up.
I mean prices are rising really fast right now.
It is a strange time in the economy. There are a lot of layoffs happening and people are just in
some really difficult financial situations.
So let's say you have a lot of debt and you want to start paying it down. How would you go about that?
The first thing I would do is take a look at all of the different kinds of debt that you have, kind of lay it all out on the table, and
what you want to look for is the debt that has the highest interest on it. Interest

is basically what the — how much your bank or 
your credit card or whoever gave you the loan

is charging you for that loan. So let's say on a 
credit card, the average interest rate is really,
Would you move it to potentially another credit card but just one with a lower interest rate?
The first thing you can do is call the card company and ask them if it's possible to lower the interest rate.
You can say things like, "I've been a really loyal customer for x number of years."
Or, "I've made all on time payments."Or, "I'm trying to get my credit in order. I'd love to continue being your customer
and you know I'd love for this relationship to continue. What are some options that I have?"
Let's say they say, "No, absolutely not. We will not lower your rate." One thing you can do is look around.
A lot of cards right now are offering really, really low rates. You can call the card that you have and say,
"Listen, I found this competitor. They're willing to offer me a credit card for x percent.
I'd love to stick with you guys. Can you match it?"

Can you also call them and ask them and just tell them what 
your financial situation is and that you're like struggling to pay it?
I would try to keep emotion out of it as much as possible, for your own sanity, but also they're a business and you are hopefully dealing with a human being,
but you don't know what rules they're following or anything, so I think rather than trying to appeal sympathetically, you're giving them information
they can give their superior.
So you were talking about paying off your credit cards first because those tend to have the highest interest rates.
What about if you have a student loan or a car loan or, I don't know, any other kind of loan?

I would look at the rates on those. Find out what your options 
are. You can always call and ask for a lower rate. Why not try?
And then I would prioritize paying off those loans by interest rate. Try to cut into those— that interest charge as much as possible
because that's the thing that will really keep you from climbing out of debt. It's like interest, when it's that high, is often designed to keep you

in debt. So like payday loans will sometimes have 
interest rates of 200 percent. You take out like a

$1000 payday loan and you miss one 
payment and, you know, suddenly you're just in

so far over your head. So you want to take care 
of that first.
So if you're thinking about trying to get financially healthy and you have all this debt but then you also want to have

some savings for next time, how do you prioritize 
which one to do?
I mean if you are dealing with a payday loan that has a huge interest rate then I would say you know what, charge— like I would

just get that debt paid off first and if an 
emergency comes up, charge it to a credit card.

But if you are dealing with student debt, say, 
I would be like, you should, you know, prioritize

having a little cushion, you know, like $500 or 
something like that, because obviously if you have

a little savings, that can prevent you from having 
to charge stuff to a credit card, which has high

interest, so you could be saving yourself money 
in the long run. If it's possible to put a little

aside I think that's always a really, really good 
idea.
So you were talking earlier about how one of the biggest misconceptions about debt is that it's a result of people being irresponsible, whereas

often it's like you had some emergency or just 
some unexpected expense that came up. I want to

acknowledge that and then also say for some folks, 
overspending can be an issue. Where would you start

if you're looking at your finances and you're 
saying, "Okay, I want to start spending a little less

so that I can put more money towards paying my 
debt down."
Even if you are really on a tight budget I think you can always look and see you know is there something that I could cut out that wouldn't

cause me much pain. Sometimes you look at 
your bank statement and you're getting charged

for things you don't even remember you were 
getting charged for. The second thing I would do

is just get a sense of overall—  use one of the 
apps, there are millions of them, just get a sense
of where your money's going. One of the things that  can be really helpful is just to figure out you

know have like a you know an aspirational budget 
or something you know so it's like, "Okay, I would

love to be saving $300 a month. For that to happen, I 
would need to spend x amount in each category." And

one of the trends in budgeting that has kind 
of resurfaced is something called cash stuffing.

You would have envelopes with like rent, 
groceries, and you would put the money in the

envelope and once the money was out of the 
envelope, you did not spend any more money

on groceries or going out to eat or whatever it 
was. On TikTok you can— there are millions of

videos of people, I mean hilariously, they sell 
all these cute little envelopes for your cash
that you can purchase—
Oh my God, another way to rack up debt.
They have some designer ones, which I personally found quite delightful. The irony, but you have people you know cash stuffing and people like to watch
and there is something very satisfying about watching these little stacks of cash and how organized it is.

It feels very zen. You kind of, you're seeing every charge. 
You're feeling it. It's going through your hands.

I went grocery shopping with a woman who was 
spending only cash and you know she was just— she shopped in a way that was like
very different from how she used to shop. She looked at the price of everything. She compared prices.
She thought about like you know she was like, "Okay, I have to— this money has to last me for— this food has to last me for two weeks." So it's like it's just a little

bit of a different mentality, and she was paying 
down $18,000 worth of credit

card debt. She's paid down $5,000 of it, but 
you know she started with that. She said she
was very embarrassed about it. She went public with it on TikTok, her names Jamie Feldman, you can find her,

um but she went public with it she said it was— 
she'd never told anybody. Her family didn't know.

Then she did a TikTok about it and she said it 
was like, she felt so ashamed, but then she said the

second she started looking at it and like put it 
all out on the table, she's like, "It came down so

fast. Because there were just stupid things I could 
do, and I was like oh I can cut this out, I can cut
this." And she said like the first like $3,000 - 4,000 were really easy and this

was probably one of the most profound on things 
that I think I learned from talking to people

about debt. I was like, "Oh is there any part of the 
grocery store you don't go in anymore? She's like, "I

don't go to the olive oil aisle." Because she's like, 
"I love the— they're so beautiful and they're these

jars of them and I always can like talk myself 
into needing some kind of like you know toasted

sesame oil or some beautiful you know balsamic 
vinegar." And it occurred to me— and I think this

is really true in debt and so many other things— 
that so much of getting some big, monstrous seeming
thing— $18,000 of credit card debt, or whatever it is— under control is just these
really mundane, little, tiny day-to-day decisions.
A lot of retailers are really selling you an emotion and I think part of getting your spending under control is interrupting those emotions or

thoughts. You know, acknowledging them but 
then also thinking about, "What am I actually
longing for right now?  Maybe it's not this bottle of olive oil. Maybe it's connection with

my friends. Like I'm thinking about a dinner party." 
I could still have a dinner party without having
like this very specific product.
All right, it's time for some role play.
When you have a lot of debt, you might have to say no to social invites or requests for money, and it can be hard to communicate that.

So we're going to give you some language to do 
it.
In scenario one, Stacy and I are cousins. I'm getting married across the country and I ask her to be a bridesmaid, but she can't afford it.

Oh my gosh, I'm so honored. I am in kind of 
a stressed financial position right now and

if I were gonna be your— in your bridal party, 
I would want to like really do it right because I

don't know. You always had such amazing taste and 
I'm sure that there's like a beautiful dress and

it's going to be such a fun party. I just, I 
just— I wouldn't want to— I feel like I would

bring the whole bridal party down if I were 
part of it honestly because I just don't have

money to spend. If that's okay and you would not 
mind having me in your party, if like I wouldn't

necessarily have to buy a dress or anything like 
that, I would be so honored and happy to join or

play whatever role. I can give a toast whatever 
you need. It's just that that particular role,

just because I'm just my finances are so tight 
right now, I just I don't think I can do that.

I'm so sorry to hear that. I didn't realize you 
were going through that.
Yeah it's been a little stressful. I mean, it's under control. It's okay, but I just— part— a lot of it is having to do things that

are really hard like saying no when like a really 
dear friend asks you something that you really

want to say yes to. It means a lot to me that you 
asked. Thank you for asking.
Yeah totally.
Okay, love you, bye!
The one thing these conversations might allow you to do is be vulnerable with people who you are close with and share something that
might allow them to support you in some way, even if that's just more emotional and social.
There's a big emotional component to debt for sure and yeah, I think you're right. I think that is like there's an opening there, which is like

a really important thing to remember. It's not 
necessarily just like this grim, terrible, "I can't."

All right, scenario two: Stacey and I are no longer 
cousins. Now we're dating. I love going out to fancy

restaurants and she just can't afford to keep 
doing that.
Babe, I wanted to talk with you about something. I know we've been going out to eat a lot and that that is something that you love and

I love going out to eat too. That is really fun 
and I also just like love how much you love it

and how excited you get. I looked at my budget 
last month and I don't think it's like quite

in my budget to keep eating out as much as we've 
been. I went through a period where I lost my job

for a while and I didn't have any savings at that 
point so I put a bunch of money on credit cards
and I have about $30,000 in debt.
I just like, I don't know. It just seems like pretty irresponsible for you to have like gotten into that much debt honestly.

I and like I don't see why I should have to be like eating in all 
the time.
I want you to know that I'm not like an irresponsible person and I would be happy to go out to eat but it might just have to be like a

ramen bar or something instead of somewhere fancy. 
Or like if going out to like a really nice place

is something you want to do, like I am totally cool 
if you want to go with friends or other things
um to maybe like be able to experience those things and those places and maybe
we can find something else that's just a little more within my budget.

Okay, time for scenario three. Stacey and I are now 
co-workers and I am organizing a group gift for
our colleague's son's kindergarten graduation.
Hey Stacey. Um as a team we we really want to celebrate little Timmy and so if you could just Venmo me like 50 bucks, that should cover it .
I'll send you my Venmo handle for that.
That is so sweet. I I really I mean I don't know that's just a very thoughtful thing.
I love that I work on a team where we like are this thoughtful. Financially, I can't do that right now. I don't have— I don't have the extra money

right now. I am so sorry. If you want to like make 
that clear to her, like sign a card or like— I

know that's going to mean extra money for you 
guys and I am I am sorry about that. I'm happy

to help in other ways. I could book something 
or if there's something I can do that doesn't

involve money, I'm more than happy to help and 
or pitch in any way I can.
Okay, thanks!
[Laughter]
Because unfortunately I do think that that is the response you might get like, "Okay
thanks." But there's a lot behind it.
Judging, judging. And you know what? People
like they have a right to their own thoughts, as wrong as those thoughts may be.

Money is this like stand-in for so many things 
for people and it gets tied into feelings of like

security, freedom, possibility, adventure, opportunity, 
intelligence, all this stuff. And so when people are

talking about money they're almost always talking 
about something else and it's not usually what you

associate with money. So if I associate money with 
like security and you like make some comment to me

about how I spend my money, it's probably coming 
from a place of you seeing it as possibility or
something else, so like we're actually not speaking the same language, even

though we think we are because money is like 
an abstraction of value.
I think it's helpful to think about when do you disclose the details of your financial situation?
Pretend like you're your own friend, right, I mean how would you talk about a friend? I wouldn't say you know well you know

Marielle can't contribute $50 because she's in 
$30,000 worth of credit card debt.

That would be really nasty. So why would 
I do that about myself if it wasn't to someone

I trusted? It's important to just keep in mind 
that you don't owe anybody an explanation. It's

not their business. One thing you can always say: "It 
doesn't feel right to me right now, but please do

keep me in mind for the future." "It doesn't feel 
right to me" is very hard to argue with

because people are like, "Why not?" "I don't know. 
It just doesn't." Or, "I'm just I'm not going to be

able— like it's not going to work with my schedule 
for the wedding." If you don't feel comfortable

talking about money at all, you don't have to. 
That information is something you should only give

up to the point you're comfortable and probably 
underestimate your comfort level. You just wanna
take care of yourself in these situations.
Yeah, I love that.
If you had to pick a word that we should use when approaching a big pile of debt, what's the one word that you should approach that debt with.
I would say daily because I think debt can feel so overwhelming

but I think it is it is nothing more and nothing 
less than like a daily commitment. Dealing with

debt is change— making lifestyle changes. Making 
lifestyle changes is one of the hardest things

that you can do. And I think to recognize 
and to honor like the size and the scope of

what you're doing and to respect yourself for 
that but to know that it's going to feel like

this little daily grind, which is like every day 
just like tackle what you can do in that one day.
And I think that's the best way to deal with debt and with a lot of things, honestly.

Daily reminders of why you're doing this, daily attempts to find 
other things that allow you to care for yourself

without spending loads of money, daily culling of 
your friend group to make sure that—
—honing, I prefer the term honing
— only the good ones remain.
Yes, wheat from the chaff.
Stacey, thank you so much for being here.
Yes, anytime.
And thanks for playing along with all this.
Absolutely, that was really fun.
All right, time for a recap.
Pay off your debt with the highest interest rate first. If you have other credit card offers, use them as leverage. Ask your credit card company to match

the lower interest rate. Once you've paid off your 
loans with super high interest rates, try to put a

little bit of money in savings every month while 
you pay off the rest of your debt, even if it's

the tiniest amount. That way you'll have money set 
aside for emergencies and you won't have to put

them on a credit card in the future. And remember, 
there's a lot of judgment around debt so when

you're navigating conversations about it, protect 
yourself. You don't owe anyone the details.
[Music]
